facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 447 of 1971 is an appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated September 15, 1970 of the Madras High Court in C.R.P. No. 797 of 1970.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 447 of 1971. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated September 15, 1970 of the Madras High Court in C.R.P. No. 797 of 1970, C. Setalvad, and K. Jayaram, for the, appellant.

facts.text: The order dated March 31, 1969, passed by the Court of Small Causes, Madras, in H.R.C. No. 983 of 1968 directed the eviction of the respondent-tenant.

anchor.surface_text: The short question that arises for companysi- deration in this appeal, by special leave, is whether the order dated March 31, 1969, passed by the Court of Small Causes, Madras, in H.R.C. No. 983 of 1968 directing the eviction of the respondenttenant is a nullity and as such number executable.

facts.text: Appellant occupied premises in Madras as a tenant; landlady filed H.R.C. No. 1924 of 1967 seeking eviction on ground of bona fide requirement for own occupation.

anchor.surface_text: The facts leading upto the passing of the order may be stated The appellant was occupying a premises in Madras as a tenant. His landlady filed an application H.R.C. No. 1924 of 1967 seeking eviction of the appellant on the ground that she bona fide required die premises for her own occupation.

facts.text: Appellant purchased the suit premises No. 64, Lloyds Road, Royapettah, Madras-14 on October 23, 1967, as per registered document No. 1633 of 1967.

anchor.surface_text: At that time the suit premises No. 64, Lloyds Road, Royaspettah, Madras-14 was advertised for sale. The appellant for purposes of his occupation purchased the premises on October 23, 1967, as per registered document No. 1633 of 1967 in Sub-Registrars Office, Mylapore.

facts.text: Respondent was tenant of the suit premises under the vendor and after purchase attorned in favour of the appellant and has been paying rent.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent was then a tenant of the suit premises under the vendor. After the purchase, he attorned in favour of the appellant and has been paying rent.

facts.text: Eviction order passed against appellant in H.R.C. No. 1924 of 1967 on January 27, 1968, with time till January 27, 1969 to vacate.

anchor.surface_text: An eviction order was passed by companysent against the appellant in H.R.C. No. 1924 of 1967 on January 27,1968. He was given time till January 27, 1969, to vacate the premises, of which he, was in occupation as a tenant, by virtue of the said decree.

facts.text: Appellant issued two notices on January 27, 1968 to respondent terminating tenancy under section 106 of Transfer of Property Act, calling for possession on February 29, 1968.

anchor.surface_text: On the same day i.e. January 27, 1968, the appellant issued two numberices to the respondent, his tenant in respect of the suit premises, terminating tenancy of the Respondent under section 106 of the Transfer of Property Act and calling upon him to quit and deliver vacant possession on February 29, 1968.

facts.text: Appellant filed H.R.C. No. 983 of 1968 in Court of Small Causes, Madras under section 10(3)(a)(i) of Madras Buildings Lease Rent Control Act, 1960 for eviction on ground of bona fide own occupation.

anchor.surface_text: As the respondent did number surrender possession of the premises, the appellant filed H.R.C. No. 983 of 1968 in the companyrt of Small Causes, Madras, under section 10  3    a   i  of the Madras Buildings  Lease Rent Control  Act, 1960  hereinafter referred to as the Act .

facts.text: Respondent filed counter-affidavit on July 19, 1968 denying he is tenant, claiming Ms. M. Seshadri is tenant.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent filed two companynter-affidavits, one on July 19, 1968 and another on January 14, 1969. In the former he has raised the companytention that he is number a tenant of the suit premises, either under the appellant or under the previous owner of the premises.

facts.text: In additional counter-affidavit on January 14, 1969, respondent disputed bona fides of appellant's requirement, eviction order against appellant, lawfulness of purchase, and notices.

anchor.surface_text: In ,the additional companynter-affidavit, the respondent pleaded that the appellant does number require the house for his occupation and that his claim is number bona fide. He has also companytroverted the claim of the appellant that an eviction order had been passed against him in H.R.C. No. 1924 of 1967.

facts.text: Enquiry in HRC 983/1968 commenced on January 16, 1969; appellant examined as PW1 till February 20, 1969, filed exhibits including P-45 (eviction order).

anchor.surface_text: The enquiry before the Court of Small Causes. appears to have companymenced on January 16, 1969. The appellant was examined on that day as PW 1 and his evidence appears to have spread over till February 20, 1969.

facts.text: On March 31, 1969, parties entered compromise: respondent withdraws defence, submits to unconditional eviction decree, time till June 5, 1969 to vacate.

anchor.surface_text: On March 31, 1969, both parties entered into a companypromise in the following terms MEMO OF COMPROMISE The Respondent hereby withdraws his defence in the aforesaid petition and submits to a decree for eviction unconditionally.

facts.text: Court of Small Causes passed consent eviction order on March 31, 1969 incorporating compromise terms, granting time till June 5, 1969.

anchor.surface_text: The companyrt, after referring to the petition of the landlord- being under section 10 3   a   i  of the Act on the ground of his own occupation, passed the following order - Compromise memo filed and recorded. By companysent eviction is ordered granting time to vacate till 5-6-1969.

facts.text: Appellant paid Rs. 20,000 to respondent on March 31, 1969 towards repairs and improvements.

anchor.surface_text: it is also seen from the records that the appellant paid a sum of Rs. 20,000/- on March 31, 1969, to the respondent towards the companyt of repairs and improvements effected by him during his occupation of the suit premises.

facts.text: Respondent's son S.M. Sundaram filed suit in City Civil Court, Madras declaring appellant's purchase void, obtained interim injunction against execution; suit dismissed December 12, 1969.

anchor.surface_text: When the time for delivery of property was drawing near, the respondents son, one S. M. Sundaram, filed a suit in the City Civil Court, Madras, for a declaration that the purchase, by the appellant of the suit property was void.

facts.text: Appellant filed Execution Petition No. 953 of 1969 in City Civil Court to execute eviction order in HRC 983/1968.

anchor.surface_text: After the dismissal of the above suit, the appellant filed Execution Petition No. 953 of 1969 in the City Civil Court, Madras  which was the companypetent Court for purposes of execution  to execute the order of eviction against the respondent in H.R.C. No. 983 of 1968.

facts.text: Respondent filed E.A. No. 1314 of 1969 objecting to execution claiming decree nullity; City Civil Judge dismissed on March 18, 1970, time till April 20, 1970.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent filed A. No. 1314 of 1969 objecting to the execution of the decree on the ground that it was a nullity and in executable and as such he prayed for the warrant, of possession issued in Execution Petition to be recalled and to dismiss the Execution Petition itself.

facts.text: Madras High Court in C.R.P. No. 797 of 1970 reversed City Civil Court order on September 15, 1970 holding eviction order nullity.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent carried the matter to the High Court in Civil Revision Petition No. 797 of 1970. The High Court by its judgment and order dated September 15, 1970, has reversed the order of the City Civil Court and accepted the companytentions, of the respondent.

facts.text: Supreme Court allowed the appeal, set aside High Court order, restored City Civil Court order.

anchor.surface_text: In the result the appeal is allowed. The order and judgment dated September 15, 1970, of the High Court are set aside and the order dated March 18, 1970, of the City Civil Court, Madras, will stand restored with companyts throughout.

facts.text: Respondent is a retired I.C.S. officer and an advocate.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent, who is a retired I.C.S. officer and an advocate, must have been fully aware of the averments made by the landlord, the pleas raised in defence as well as the nature of the evidence led by ,.lie landlord to meet his defence.

facts.text: Respondent did not cross-examine the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent had number chosen to cross-examine the appellant.

facts.text: Appellant has no other house of his own in Madras except suit premises.

anchor.surface_text: There is a reference to the. appellant being a tenant of premises No. 2, Lakshmipuram, 1st street, Madras- 14, and to his having numberother house of his own in the city of Madras except the suit premises.

anchor.surface_text: The short question that arises for consideration in this appeal, by special leave, is whether the order dated March 31, 1969, passed by the Court of Small Causes, Madras, in H.R.C. No. 983 of 1968 directing the eviction of the respondenttenant is a nullity and as such number executable.

issues.text: whether in the case before us, it can be stated that the Controller was so satisfied when he passed the order of eviction on March 31, 1969

anchor.surface_text: The question is whether in the case before us, it can be stated that the Controller was so satisfied when he passed the order of eviction on March 31, 1969.

issues.text: whether the decree for eviction has been passed solely on the basis of the compromise arrived at between the parties

anchor.surface_text: We are not inclined to accept the contention of Mr. Tarkunde that the decree for eviction in the case before us has been passed solely on the basis of the compromise arrived at between the parties.

issues.text: whether the executing Court can consider whether from the materials on record the Rent Control Court was satisfied about the bona fide requirement

anchor.surface_text: Once it is accepted that the question about a decree being void and as such not executable on any ground available in law can be raised before the executing Court

issues.text: whether satisfaction of the Court can be inferred if a stage had been reached for the court to apply its mind to the statutory condition and there was sufficient material on record

anchor.surface_text: If a stage had been reached in a particular proceeding for a court to apply its mind regarding the existence of a statutory condition, it may be held that it was so satisfied about the plea of the landlord.

anchor.surface_text: His withdrawal of the defence, after the plaintiff had given evidence and filed exhibits in support of his plea, clearly shows that he accepted as true the claim of the landlord

issues.text: whether a quasi-judicial tribunal like Rent Controller requires explicit satisfaction manifested by judicial finding for eviction order based on compromise or can act on tenant's admission
whether compromise decrees for eviction in rent control proceedings are necessarily void absent explicit court satisfaction of statutory ground

arguments.claim: The eviction decree is a nullity because it contravenes section 10 of the Act as passed solely on compromise without Rent Controller satisfying itself independently about bona fide requirement

anchor.surface_text: The respondent filed A. No. 1314 of 1969 objecting to the execution of the decree on the ground that it was a nullity and in executable and as such he prayed for the warrant, of possession issued in Execution Petition to be recalled and to dismiss the Execution Petition itself. His main plea in this appli- cation was that the decree sought to be executed was one based on companypromise or companysent without the Rent Control Court having satisfied itself by an independent companysideration regarding the bona fide requirement of the property by the landlord for his own occupation and as such the decree companytravened section 10 of the Act.

arguments.court_reasoning: Satisfaction inferred from evidence led, stage reached, tenant's withdrawal of defence admitting claim; not solely on compromise

arguments.claim: Decree does not suffer infirmity; evidence adduced showed case true, tenant withdrew defence when pleas unsustainable

anchor.surface_text: This application was opposed by the appellant in a lengthy companynter-affidavit. arguments.court_reasoning: High Court erred; satisfaction can be inferred without explicit expression

arguments.claim: High Court misunderstood SC precedents; appellant pleaded/supported bona fides with evidence/exhibits; tenant no cross-exam, withdrew defence accepting claim; court satisfied, not solely compromise

anchor.surface_text: Mr. M. C. Setalvad, learned companynsel for the appellant, has urged that the High Court has misunderstood and, misinterpreted the decisions of this Court hearing on the point. He- pointed out that the appellant had specifically pleaded that be required the house bona fide for his own occupation... That companyduct of the respondent clearly establishes that he has accepted as true the claim of the landlord that he bona fide required the premises for his own use and occupation.

arguments.court_reasoning: Agrees; distinguishes precedents as no evidence/admission there; here stage reached, material, admission

arguments.claim: Decree passed exclusively on compromise; no indication court satisfied re bona fides; mandatory satisfaction required; executing court cannot enquire into materials/satisfaction

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Tarkunde, learned companynsel for the respondent, urged that the decree for eviction has been passed exclusively on the basis of the companypromise entered into by the parties. There is numberindication that the companyrt at any stage applied its mind and satisfied itself regarding the premises being required by the landlord bona fide for his own occupation.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: property and the Rent Controller cannot pass a valid order merely because the tenant submits to an order of eviction. Bahadur Singhs case is an insta

arguments.court_reasoning: Executing court can consider materials to check nullity; satisfaction inferred here

arguments.claim: Satisfaction required under s10(3)(e); must be explicit or inferable; here inferable as stage reached for mind application, sufficient material, tenant admission via withdrawal

anchor.surface_text: In the last decision, in our opinion, there is an indication as to how the satisfaction of a companyrt can be expressed or gathered in a particular case. If a stage had been reached in a particular proceeding for a companyrt to apply its mind regarding the existence of a satutory companydition, it may be held that it was so satisfied about the plea of the landlord.

arguments.claim: Decree not solely on compromise; order refers to s10(3)(a)(i) ground; satisfaction from evidence stage, no cross, withdrawal=acceptance of bona fides

anchor.surface_text: We are number inclined to accept the companytention of Mr. Tarkunde that the decree for eviction in the case before us has been passed solely on the basis of the companypromise arrived at between the parties. No doubt a reading of the order of the companyrt dated March 31, 1969, isolated from all other circumstances, may give the impression that the decree for eviction is passed because of the companypromise between the parties.

arguments.claim: Bahadur Singh precedent: nullity where no party landlord, no court satisfaction of ground

anchor.surface_text: In Bahadur Singh Anr. v. Muni Subrat Dass Anr., 1  a decree for eviction passed on the basis of a companypromise between the parties, was held, by this Court, to be a nullity as companytravening section 13 1  of the Delhi and Ajmer Rent Control Act, 1952... This Court held that the decree directing the tenant to deliver possession of the premises to the landlord was a nullity, as it was passed in companytravention of section 13 1  of the relevant statute.

arguments.claim: Kaushalya Devi precedent: nullity where compromise before evidence, no indication of ground satisfaction

anchor.surface_text: In Kaushalya Devi Ors. v. Shri K. L. Bansal,  2  the ques- tion again arose under the same Delhi statute regarding the validity  1  1969 2 S.C.R. 432.  2  1969 2 S.C.R. 1048. of a decree passed for eviction on companypromise... Following the decision in Bahadur Singh Anr., 1  this Court upheld the order of the High Court.

arguments.claim: Ferozi Lal precedent: nullity where no stage for mind application, no material showing satisfaction, solely compromise

anchor.surface_text: A similar question came up again before this Court in Ferozi Lal Jain v. Man Mal Anr.  2  The landlord filed an application for eviction of the tenant on the ground that he had sublet the premises... Hence the decree under execution must be held to be a nullity.

arguments.court_reasoning: Distinguishable: here evidence led, exhibits, no cross, withdrawal after

arguments.claim: Executing court can adjudicate nullity plea by considering relevant materials on record

anchor.surface_text: Once it is accepted that the question about a decree being void and as such number executable on any ground available in law can be raised before the executing Court, it is needless to state that the executing Court will have to adjudicate upon that plea and for that purpose the relevant materials have to be companysidered.

arguments.claim: Tenant's withdrawal of defence after evidence/exhibits = admission of landlord's bona fide claim

anchor.surface_text: His withdrawal of the defence, after the plaintiff had given evidence and filed exhibits in support of his plea, clearly shows that he accepted as true the claim of the landlord that he requires the premises bona fide for his own occupation.

arguments.claim: Satisfaction need not be explicit judicial finding; can act on tenant admission without further enquiry if statutory ground pleaded

anchor.surface_text: But if the tenant in fact admits that the landlord is entitled to possession on one or other of the statutory grounds mentioned in the Act, it is open to the companyrt to act on that admission and make an order for possession in favour of the landlord without further enquiry.

arguments.claim: Tenant disputed title/notice but withdrew all defences unconditionally; those pleas no longer survive

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Tarkunde, learned companynsel, companytended that the tenant had disputed the title of the landlord as well as the validity of the numberice issued under section 106 of the Transfer of Property Act. As these matters have number been companysidered by the companyrts below... The tenant raised these objections also in his original plea, but he has unconditionally withdrawn all his defence.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: then ready to go out  number that he was once willing but has changed his mind  should number make an order for possession. Lord Atkin L. J. observed

arguments.claim: Rent Controller quasi-judicial with limited jurisdiction; compromise valid if on statutory ground, like civil suit; no special satisfaction beyond civil standards
No objection to compromise consenting to eviction if landlord pleaded statutory ground; tenant not minor requiring extra satisfaction

holdings.text: The order dated March 31, 1969, passed by the Court of Small Causes, Madras, in H.R.C. No. 983 of 1968 directing the eviction of the respondent-tenant is not a nullity and is executable.

anchor.surface_text: The short question that arises for consideration in this appeal, by special leave, is whether the order dated March 31, 1969, passed by the Court of Small Causes, Madras, in H.R.C. No. 983 of 1968 directing the eviction of the respondenttenant is a nullity and as such not executable.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Satisfaction of Controller's bona fide requirement inferred from landlord's evidence and exhibits filed, tenant's failure to cross-examine, and unconditional withdrawal of defense admitting claim; distinguishes precedents where no such material or admission.

holdings.text: In the case before us, it can be stated that the Controller was so satisfied when he passed the order of eviction on March 31, 1969.

anchor.surface_text: The question is whether in the case before us, it can be stated that the Controller was so satisfied when he passed the order of eviction on March 31, 1969.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Stage reached where landlord examined, exhibits filed including eviction order against him; tenant no cross-exam, withdrew defense after evidence supporting bona fides.

holdings.text: The decree for eviction has not been passed solely on the basis of the compromise arrived at between the parties.

anchor.surface_text: We are not inclined to accept the contention of Mr. Tarkunde that the decree for eviction in the case before us has been passed solely on the basis of the compromise arrived at between the parties.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Order refers to s.10(3)(a)(i); satisfaction from proceedings stage, evidence, tenant admission via withdrawal; not isolated compromise.

holdings.text: The executing Court can consider whether from the materials on record the Rent Control Court was satisfied about the bona fide requirement.

anchor.surface_text: Once it is accepted that the question about a decree being void and as such not executable on any ground available in law can be raised before the executing Court

holdings.reasoning_summary: Under s.47 CPC, executing court adjudicates nullity pleas by considering relevant record materials.

holdings.text: Satisfaction of the Court can be inferred if a stage had been reached for the court to apply its mind to the statutory condition and there was sufficient material on record.

anchor.surface_text: If a stage had been reached in a particular proceeding for a court to apply its mind regarding the existence of a statutory condition, it may be held that it was so satisfied about the plea of the landlord.

holdings.reasoning_summary: From Ferozi Lal Jain, infer satisfaction if proceedings advanced to evidence stage with material before compromise; applies to jurisdictional fact under rent acts.

holdings.text: The tenant's unconditional withdrawal of defence after landlord's evidence amounts to admission that the landlord's bona fide requirement is established.

anchor.surface_text: His withdrawal of the defence, after the plaintiff had given evidence and filed exhibits in support of his plea, clearly shows that he accepted as true the claim of the landlord

holdings.reasoning_summary: Tenant aware, no cross-exam, withdrew all defenses including denial of bona fides post-evidence.

holdings.text: A quasi-judicial tribunal like Rent Controller does not require explicit satisfaction manifested by judicial finding for eviction order based on compromise if statutory ground pleaded and tenant admits; can act on admission.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Analogous to CPC compromise; no special rule like minors; jurisdiction if ground alleged and admitted; distinguishes unlimited civil court jurisdiction.

holdings.text: Compromise decrees for eviction in rent control proceedings are not necessarily void absent explicit court satisfaction of statutory ground.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Valid if landlord pleaded statutory ground and tenant consents post-material; no extra satisfaction beyond civil standards; English precedents support acting on admission.

precedents.case_name: Ferozi Lal Jain v. Man Mal
precedents.cited_proposition: decree for eviction on compromise without court satisfaction on statutory ground like subletting is nullity

edges.explanation: Section 47 CPC, permitting executing court to consider decree nullity, addresses the issue of whether it can examine Rent Control Court's satisfaction on bona fide requirement.
The principle supports the finding that the decree was not solely based on compromise by providing the analogous legal framework.
The analogous application of Order 23 Rule 3 CPC grounds the holding that compromise decrees in rent control are not necessarily void without explicit statutory satisfaction.
The principle's analogous application to rent control compromise proceedings addresses whether the eviction decree was solely based on compromise.
Analogous application of Order 23 Rule 3 CPC to rent control compromise decrees directly addresses the validity of such decrees absent statutory ground satisfaction.

No CPC O32R7-like requirement for tenants undercuts need for explicit satisfaction in compromise decrees, supporting they are not necessarily void (defeats strict natural justice speaking order demand)

The concept c9 that the Rent Controller is not an ordinary civil court with unlimited jurisdiction grounds the holding h7 by establishing the quasi-judicial nature that permits eviction orders based on compromise without explicit judicial satisfaction when a statutory ground is pleaded.

The concept c9 regarding the limited jurisdiction of the Rent Controller as not an ordinary civil court addresses the issue i7 concerning procedural requirements for explicit satisfaction in eviction orders by compromise.

anchor.surface_text: The short question that arises for consideration in this appeal, by special leave, is whether the order dated March 31, 1969, passed by the Court of Small Causes, Madras, in H.R.C. No. 983 of 1968 directing the eviction of the respondenttenant is a nullity and as such not executable.

In the result the appeal is allowed. The order and judgment dated September 15, 1970, of the High Court are set aside and the order dated March 18, 1970, of the City Civil Court, Madras, will stand restored with costs throughout.
